Posts.Content: super-sandra wrote: Hello I have never entered anything on a forum before, but on stumbling across this site I thought it may be helpful, to me, if I did.  I recently detected a lump, which subsequently turned out to be a large cyst which I then had aspirated.  The mammogram detected a cluster of calcifications in my right breast.  The doctor told me these are indeterminate - a biopsy was done 3 days ago and I go back for the results next week - it feels like forever, though will only have been 7 days.  The Advanced Practitioner that carried out the biopsy informed me that the calcifications are very fine grains like sand - I can only assume that means they are micro calcifications?  I have no other information as I could not take anything in at the time, which is very frustrating as ordinarily I like to know everything there is to know!  I have read so much about calcifications and the information that I have about my situation does not read very favourably.  Has anyone else found themselves in a similar situation?  I'm just very worried! Posts.Content: super wrote: My future mother-in-law was diagnosed with Stage 2a breast cancer. She underwent modified radical mastectomy for the left breast with lymph node dissection. The tumor is an invasive ductal carcinoma just a little over 2 cm in diameter. There were no lymph node metastasis or any other metastasis. The surgeon, who i agree with, says that she doesnt need chemotherapy. I was inside the Operating room when she had her mastectomy and the lymph nodes really were so small that it was hard to locate. Are there any specialists out there who can give an opinion? Most oncologists would recommend chemo but since it is a ductal carcinoma and with the affected breast remove, i really dont want to have her go through chemo after the surgical ordeal.
